In addition, after resolving the issues, please squash your commits and use imperative for your commit message per guidelines.

Just squashed and re-worded to use imperative. AFAIK, the old library is python 3 compatible. I didn't use the new library because it is still in alpha/beta and, from personal experience, isn't quite ready for production use (as far as feature completeness is concerned). The developers also aren't guaranteeing API stability yet.

Nice catch. This functionality was broken by https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/4ffa5834 (cc @mistercrunch) We ran into other similar breakage from that PR and it looks like our current unit tests don't catch it. The only way to find similar bugs is currently via running commands via the command line. Any ideas how to protect ourselves going forward?

IMO, Yes but maybe not. Essentially you have a task in hand to move MySql(RDS) data to S3. You can use airflow for such a task using MySql and S3 operators. But, since you are moving data from RDS to S3, you should take a look at AWS pipelines. You could still use airflow to schedule and define the jobs that run the data transfer.

I need to think about that a little bit on how to approach that and put it in contrib. If you have a suggestion that would be nice.

Could you elaborate about the (remaining) concerns as it was reviewed by @criccomini and @jlowin ? As it stands if you don't use ZIPs nothing will change, if I make it configurable the code won't be evaluated. I could refactor the code and split the function and make it more clear what code paths are used if that helps, but there seems to be an underlying issue that I can't make out.

@underyx Here you go!
cc @mistercrunch @criccomini @bolkedebruin @jlowin 

I've added 4 short-cuts: `@now`, `@latest`, `@start_date`, and `@end_date` to `airflow test`

I will be adding documentation as well, but here is how this works:

**@now**
This passes `datettime.datetime.now()` as the task execution date

```
airflow test simple_dummy_once_dag_v1 run_this @now
[2016-04-19 23:19:13,543] {models.py:1191} INFO - Executing <Task(DummyOperator): run_this> on 2016-04-19 23:19:13.512938
```

**@start_date**
This raises an exception if the dag has no start_date. Otherwise, the dag's start date will be used. For example, the dag `simple_dummy_dag_v2` has a start_date of `2016-03-26 00:00:00`

```
airflow test simple_dummy_dag_v2 run_this @start_date
[2016-04-19 23:25:02,732] {models.py:1191} INFO - Executing <Task(DummyOperator): run_this> on 2016-03-26 00:00:00
```

**@end_date**
This raises an exception if the dag has no end_date. Otherwise, the dag's end date will be used. For example, the dag `simple_dummy_dag_v3` has a `start_date` of `2016-03-26 00:00:00` and an `end_date` of `2016-03-29 00:00:00`. Dag `simple_dummy_dag_v4` has a `start_date` of `2016-03-26 00:00:00` and an `end_date` of `2016-05-29 00:00:00`. Note: the code does not forbid future end_dates

_Non-future end_date_

```
airflow test simple_dummy_dag_v3 run_this @end_date
[2016-04-19 23:36:02,611] {models.py:1191} INFO - Executing <Task(DummyOperator): run_this> on 2016-03-29 00:00:00
```

_Future end_date_

```
airflow test simple_dummy_dag_v4 run_this @end_date
[2016-04-19 23:36:56,767] {models.py:1191} INFO - Executing <Task(DummyOperator): run_this> on 2016-05-29 00:00:00
```

**@latest**
This passes the latest day while honoring the start and end dates of a DAG as the task execution date. If the DAG has a schedule interval of `None` or `@once`, datetime.datetime.now() is used. If the DAG has a different schedule interval, an exception is raised if the dag has no `start_date`. For example, the dag `simple_dummy_dag_v2` has a `start_date` of `2016-03-26 00:00:00` and no `end_date` (and a schedule interval of `@daily`. The dag `simple_dummy_dag_v3` has a `start_date` of `2016-03-26 00:00:00` and an `end_date` of `2016-03-29 00:00:00`. Dag `simple_dummy_dag_v4` has a `start_date` of `2016-03-26 00:00:00` and an `end_date` of `2016-05-29 00:00:00`. Note: the code does not forbid future end_dates as shown below

_Non-future end_date_

```
airflow test simple_dummy_dag_v3 run_this @latest
[2016-04-19 23:36:02,611] {models.py:1191} INFO - Executing <Task(DummyOperator): run_this> on 2016-03-29 00:00:00
```

_Future end_date_

```
airflow test simple_dummy_dag_v4 run_this @latest
[2016-04-19 23:36:56,767] {models.py:1191} INFO - Executing <Task(DummyOperator): run_this> on 2016-05-29 00:00:00
```

_No end_date_

```
airflow test simple_dummy_dag_v2 run_this @latest
[2016-04-21 00:41:43,126] {models.py:1191} INFO - Executing <Task(DummyOperator): run_this> on 2016-04-20 00:00:00
```

Coverage increased (+0.1%) to 67.172% when pulling **0670f16a1ebd06f9cc1882540cd60c045c3a2ca9 on r39132:master** into **c1f485f8475300d5fd26a02af751f376ad21909b on airbnb:master**.

> it seems specific to your environment.

@mistercrunch, I actually think that deploying DAGs via git is a bit specific to your environment. I know it's how FB does it with dataswarm, but this is a really uncommon practice across a wide range of systems. If you look at virtually every other scheduler, as well as most other distributed deployment systems (mesos, YARN, Kubernetes, etc), none of them deploy code this way.

I'm in a similar position to Bolke--installing a bunch of teams' packages in either the Airflow virtual environment, or the system's Python space is not easily do-able.

What are the exact concerns? I see two, so far:
1. The sys.path issue.
2. The Docker vs. Zip issue.

(1), I'm not well versed to comment on, so I'll leave you two to it. :) For (2), even if Docker DAG packages are supported, for those not using Docker, one could argue that supporting zip deployables might be nice. It's kind of a kitchen sink approach, though, so I'm more in favor of an either/or (I prefer to have the framework be opinionated).

Maybe you could shed some light on what the Docker proposal looks like, when it might be implemented, etc?

I can confirm that PR-[#855](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/855) does not really solve the issue with supervisor, as supervisor is explicitly designed to handle processes in the foreground. And I agree with @t1m0thy that the PR introducing daemon behavior is orthogonal to how running the webserver in the foreground is done. The argument against using `os.exec*` was that it is deprecated, but is that really the case? `os.popen` and `os.spawn*` surely are deprecated, but as far as I know, the `os.exec*` family is still the standard way of replacing the process image with that of another process?

Wow, that's just lovely, awesome job, @r39132!

If you're okay with nitpicking, I'd mention that I'm not sure if `@start` / `@end` wouldn't already be just as clear as `@start_date` / `@end_date`, with shorter names (which is certainly an advantage when the feature is directed at the lazy  ).

Airflow is for running tasks, but what those tasks do is up to you. One of the most common use cases for Airflow is moving data from one place to another. However, if all you want to do is move data one time, then Airflow is not the right tool. If you want to move data regularly, then Airflow will schedule your tasks and make sure they run.

I think you are right on the os.exec part, my apologies it should not have been added to the discussion. However. subprocess.Popen uses os.execvp underneath, so I am not sure what problem I'll be solving. It also replaces the current process so there should not be a need to do separate signaling. 

Can you provide some output on what is happening (I dont run supervisord) (process lists, debug output) and I'll gladly look at the issue @amerkel2
@WesleyBatista going to close this if I don't hear back within 24h.

The problem is that `subprocess.Popen` does a `fork()` (in `_posixsubprocess.fork_exec()`) before the `os.execvp`. This creates a child process, which is then replaced by `gunicorn`, so the original `airflow scheduler` process still lives on:

```
init(1)
     supervisord(10778)airflow(20833)gunicorn: maste(20838)gunicorn: worke(20852)
                                                                   gunicorn: worke(20853)
                                                                   gunicorn: worke(20854)
                                                                   gunicorn: worke(20859)
```

Supervisor, when terminating the webserver, kills the airflow process, leaving the gunicorn alive since airflow does no signal propagation. So the situation afterwards is an orphaned gunicorn directly attached to `init`:

```
init(1)
     gunicorn: maste(20838)gunicorn: worke(20852)
                             gunicorn: worke(20853)
                             gunicorn: worke(20854)
                             gunicorn: worke(20859)
```

On the other hand, if `os.execvp` were done directly by Airflow instead of using `subprocess.popen`, the fork would not be done and the airflow process replaced by gunicorn:

```
init(1)
     supervisord(10778)gunicorn: maste(20838)gunicorn: worke(20852)
                                                  gunicorn: worke(20853)
                                                  gunicorn: worke(20854)
                                                  gunicorn: worke(20859)
```

supervisor would then terminate the gunicorn master process (since this is the process that has replaced the airflow process that supervisor spawned), which does signal propagation to its children and everything would be properly terminated.

You may be able to get away with calling `os.killpg` on the process that starts gunicorn.

``` python
# Put this after opening up the guinicorn subprocesses
# https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/airbnb_1.7.1rc2/airflow/bin/cli.py#L349
atexit.register(cleanup)

def cleanup():
    os.killpg(sp.pid, signal.SIGTERM)
```

I tested that locally, and calling `os.killpg` on the webserver process does bring down all the gunicorn processes with it.

@bolkedebruin , thanks for considering this issue again. I'll be happy to test the PR in our setup.
Concerning pidproxy: yes, this would work in the supervisord case, but would only solve half of our problems. We are also running Airflow on an Aurora/Mesos cluster and have the same issues there with stopping the webserver. Currently, we resort to not using the `airflow webserver` command at all and directly call `gunicorn` with the parameters that `airflow webserver` uses. So I think a solution that allows to properly terminate a non-daemonized webserver still has its use cases.

@sdiazb sorry to leave you hanging -- I don't think I have a preference either way. The db commands are really only called from the CLI so I think the cli arg is fine.

@stranbird I may not be following your question exactly -- but in general I wouldn't associate dagruns and XComs directly. The best counterexample is that I could run a single task independent of any dagrun (for example, `airflow run task`) and it could produce an XCom. In other words, XComs are "more granular" than DagRuns. Does that answer your question?
